context: The emergence of <a4_0>resistance of bacteria<a4_0/> to antibiotics is a common phenomenon. Emergence of resistance often reflects <a0_0><a5_0><b8_0><b12_0>evolution<b12_0/><a5_0/>ary processes<b8_0/><a0_0/> that take place during antibiotic therapy. The antibiotic treatment may select for bacterial strains with physiologically or genetically enhanced capacity to <a1_0><b9_0>survive high doses of antibiotics<b9_0/><a1_0/>. Under certain conditions, it may result in preferential growth of <b11_0>resistant bacteria<b11_0/>, while growth of susceptible bacteria is inhibited by the drug. For example, antibacterial selection for strains having previously acquired antibacterial-resistance genes was demonstrated in <a2_0><a6_0><b10_0>1943<b10_0/><a6_0/><a2_0/> by the <a3_0>Luria–Delbrück<a3_0/> experiment. Antibiotics such as <a7_0>penicillin and erythromycin<a7_0/>, which used to have a high efficacy against many bacterial species and strains, have become less effective, due to the increased resistance of many bacterial strains.
